 Actually, no one is using this new case to show why you really can't have abortion. The point is that the Constitution does not say that state governments can take someone's property for private use and it also doesn't say that one person can deprive another person of life, liberty, or property without due process of law. The point isn't to just be consistent. The point is to be consistent within the constraints of the Constitution, something neither Roe v Wade nor Kelo v City of New London does.
